title.value: Learnable Filters for Geometric Scattering Modules
title.justification: The title is directly mentioned at the beginning of the paper, making it clear that this is the full title.
title.quote: Learnable Filters for Geometric Scattering Modules

extractions.description: The paper introduces a new graph neural network module called the learnable geometric scattering (LEGS) module, which integrates geometric scattering transforms in a flexible and trainable manner to enhance graph neural networks. It discusses how this module can learn longer-range graph relations with fewer parameters and demonstrates its efficiency in graph classification, particularly in biochemical domains.

type.justification: The paper includes experiments and benchmarking on graph classification and regression tasks.
type.quote: We demonstrate the predictive performance of LEGS-based networks on graph classification benchmarks, as well as the descriptive quality of their learned features in biochemical graph data exploration tasks.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on improving graph neural networks through the integration of learnable geometric scattering modules.
name.quote: The paper proposes a new graph neural network (GNN) module, based on relaxations of recently proposed geometric scattering transforms.

name.justification: The paper focuses on geometric scattering transforms, which are a part of geometric deep learning.
name.quote: Geometric deep learning has recently emerged as an increasingly prominent branch of deep learning.

name.justification: The paper uses concepts and techniques from graph signal processing to define and implement the geometric scattering transforms.
name.quote: Using graph signal processing terminology from [4], these issues can be partly attributed to the limited construction of convolutional filters...

name.justification: The paper applies LEGS modules to biological graph data exploration tasks, emphasizing biochemical applications.
name.quote: We demonstrate the predictive performance of LEGS-based networks on graph classification benchmarks, as well as the descriptive quality of their learned features in biochemical graph data exploration tasks.

name.justification: The paper mentions GCN as a typical implementation and discusses its limitations, which the proposed model aims to address.
name.quote: example, [4] presented a typical implementation of a GCN with a cascade of averaging (essentially low pass) filters.

is_contributed.justification: GCN is a well-known model and not contributed by this paper. It's referenced and compared against the newly proposed LEGS module.
is_contributed.quote: example, [4] presented a typical implementation of a GCN

is_executed.justification: GCN is executed in the experiments as part of the comparative analysis.
is_executed.quote: We demonstrate the predictive performance of LEGS-based networks on graph classification benchmarks, as well as...

is_compared.justification: GCN is compared to the proposed LEGS module in experiments.
is_compared.quote: LEGS-based networks match or outperforms popular GNNs, as well as the original geometric scattering construction, on many datasets.
